segments.text: And after two years, Carl resigned as director.
And I was appointed acting director.
And I was acting director for the year 1950.
And this opposition to my being director still existed, still persisted.
But I had some powerful allies.

many of them out here at Scripps, including Detlef Bronk, who was at that time president, I guess, of Johns Hopkins University and president of the National Academy of Sciences and president of AAAS all at the same time.
And another one is a man named Bert Walford in the Bureau of Commercial Fisheries.
Bert suggested that we have a conference on the future of the Scripps Institution.
And we bring to this conference people from all over the world.
And this was at some time, I think, in the spring of 1950.
I'm pretty sure that's when it was.
Although I'm not quite sure.
I'm pretty sure it was the spring of 1950.
Maybe it was in the fall.
The reason I think it was in the spring was before the loyalty controversy erupted.
And Sproul was, of course, very much in favor of my being correct.
Bob Sproul, president of the university.
And that's why he was willing to sponsor this conference.
And he did.
And Braun came out to it.
And Columbus has a letter from Woods Hole.
a lot of guys who were good friends of mine.
And we spent three or four days talking about the future of oceanography and the future of the Scripps Institution.
And it was an inspiring affair in many ways.
Later, at the end of it, we dedicated it to Thomas Whelan Vaughan Aquarium Museum.
and Bronk made the dedication speech, and I was supposed to play a record that T. Willie, that Vaughn had made.
He couldn't, he was too old and too ill to come out himself, but he made a phonograph, I mean, a recording.
It was actually, I think, I'm not sure whether it was a tape recording or a phonograph recording, but a disc recording.
And I forgot to play the damn thing.
But anyhow, other than that, Sproul was in good form and Brock was in good form.
That was quite clear after that that I was going to be the next director.
But then we had all hell broke loose because the Regents, those were the days of McCarthy.
The Regents passed a
resolution that all faculty members had to sign a loyalty note saying they were not a communist.
Not communist.
Yeah, not a communist.
And a lot of people at Berkeley and UCLA didn't want to sign that note.
Not that they were communists, but they thought this was an infringement of academic freedom.
Maybe even some of them were communists for all I know.
I don't think, I don't think many of them were.
the worst thing about it was that the regents said if you don't sign the oath, you get fired, you get discharged.
That violated the principle of academic tenure, which I think is an absolutely fundamental principle in the university.
So none of our guys down here signed the thing.
Well, that's under my leadership.
And we were brought into the academic senate councils at UCLA and Berkeley and a lot of
My colleagues like Michael Bryan and the Dean of Engineering were on the same side.
He didn't quite understand why, but if I was on it, he was going to be on it too.
David Saxon was a very powerful, not powerful, but very dedicated man of fighting the regions to now become president of the University of California.
He's the new president.
He was a young assistant professor of physics then.
And we managed to get old Howling Mad Smith on our side.
He lived here in La Jolla.
Holland M. Smith, the great Marine Corps general.
He was a wonderful man.
He was not a West Pointer, Indianapolis man.
He was a lawyer.
Took a law degree and then went into the Marines.
Became a great general.
But he still remembered his law.
And as a lawyer, he decided that this was ridiculous, that this was really an infringement of academic freedom and a violation of tenure.
So he became an ardent supporter of our side, went to see Governor Warren.
I remember very well a couple of these little old ladies in tennis shoes with a fest La Jolla came up to him and said, General, why won't those professors sign
a simple oath saying they're not communists.
And the general turned to them in his sternest voice and manner and said, Madam, if somebody asked you to sign an oath saying you were not a whore, what would you do?
And they just, that was the last time they ever spoke to him.
And
I was one of the witnesses before the alumni committee.
So it was quite clear that I wasn't a communist, having been in the Navy for seven years and never really taken any part in political activity.
So I was a good witness.
And Don McLaughlin and Bechtel, Steve Bechtel, the head of the Bechtel Corporation, were members of this alumni committee and various other very decent citizens.
and great men in California.
And they proposed what was called the Alumni Compromise, which was that there would be a committee appointed by the Academic Senate to investigate all those people who had not signed the oath.
And that committee would recommend what should be done with each individual case like nothing
for example.
This was considered by the regents at a meeting in Davis when Governor Warren was there.
He was presiding.
The governor of California is ex officio the president of the Board of Regents, not the chairman, but the president.
But when he's there, he presides.
And the regents passed this by a pretty large majority.
This alumni compromise.
I never will forget.
I was sitting in the audience, of course.

And I never will forget that occasion because Mario Giannini, the son of AP Giannini, Mario was then head of the Bank of America, the biggest bank in the country, said, the flags will fly in the Kremlin tonight.
I hereby resign from this board of regents.
I'm going to devote the rest of my life to organizing vigilantes to fight communism.
He said just exactly those words, believe it or not.
That gives you some idea of the spirit of that awful time.
Well, you know, in Texas, we had to sign it by law.
It was passed by state law.
Any state employee had to sign the Loyalty Act, as I remember.
Well, if you have to do it by law, you've got to do it.
The Regents didn't have that legal authority.
We said we would sign it.
We would obey the law.
We wouldn't sign something that was imposed by the regents.
And Governor Warren said, Mario, you don't want to do that.
The Democratic thing to do is for you to stay here and try to convince us we're wrong.
Don't resign from the board.
Stay on the board and try to persuade us to change our mind.
Gene, nevertheless, he did resign.
And I took an oath that I would vote for Governor Warren from then on, no matter what he ran for.
Unfortunately, he never ran for anything again.
A few weeks later, he was appointed Chief Justice of the Supreme Court.
That was a 19, well, not a few weeks later, a couple of years later, actually.
This was in 1950.
And then we, then Russ Rade and I,
I guess not many other members of the faculty.
We went out on our mid-Pacific expedition in the summer of 1950.
That was a two-ship expedition.
That was the first great exploring expedition of the Scripps Institution in 1950.
We went out.
One of the things we discovered was the mid-Pacific mountains.
That's where the mountain range runs west of Hawaii.
Another was we measured the heat flow coming through the sea floor.
found that about the same as the continental heat flow.
Rust rate made a lot of seismic measurements, which showed that the sediments were only about 100 meters thick.
This was the beginning, really, of the great series of discoveries that had ended up in plate tectonics.
These seamounts, 6,000 people at the surface.
Laptop, all been at the surface.
very young, not old.
There was no place in the ocean that was very old.
It was thought that they were perhaps two billion years old, because they were so deep.
Very thin sediments, which tied in exactly with the idea that the sea floor was very young.
The heat flow, which couldn't be explained in any other way except by convection and
And later, of course, later expeditions we looked at the trenches and the mid-ocean ridges, particularly the magnetic striping, which is another story.
Well, how much longer do you want to go with that?
Starting with the Mid-Pac Expedition in 1950, we organized more and more exploring expeditions over larger and larger areas of the Pacific.
These were led by a series of inspired expedition leaders.
I led the Mid-Pacific Expedition and what we call the Capricorn Expedition.
But most of the expeditions were led by Warren Wooster and by Bill Menard, by Bob Fisher,
One was .
Those are the three that occurred to me offhand as the people who really were very good at this.
And we gradually built up our fleet of ships.
And we had more and more kinds of expeditions.
For example, we had one in the South China Sea that lasted
maybe three years, South China Sea and the Gulf of Thailand.
She called it the Naga expedition.
The leader of that started out to be a Dane named Anton Brun, but he got sick, got immediate dysentery, and was taken over by the captain, Jim Moore, also an inspiring leader.
He's a very special kind of guy.
Morris Ewing was very good at it.
Different people do it in different ways, but the essential thing is to make everybody feel that he's getting his share of the pie.
All the people on board are doing something that advances their own research interests.
And that you have adequate equipment, adequate crewing and personnel.
competent personnel, complicated planning and logistics as well as operational business.
Another man very good at this was Johnny Knauss.
In fact, we sort of specialize in producing oceanographic administrators at Scripps.
Most of the oceanographic institutions in this country are led by Scripps graduates, or partially led.
For example, Art Maxwell at Woods Hole, Johnny Knauss at Rhode Island.
Warren Wooster just retired from the Rosenstiel Laboratory at the University of Miami, Dick Fleming in Seattle, Dale Lieber in Texas A&M.
Anyhow, they had good training with being a director of an institution to lead some expeditions.
And I was pretty good at that.
I was never much of an administrator, sure, but I was a good administrator at sea.
Anyhow, about 1955, I never went to sea anymore.
One of the reasons for this was that I decided that we were not treating our graduate students very well.
I felt two things, and I always have felt.
one of them, and that is that research and teaching are inseparable.
That you just can't do a good job of teaching without research, and you can't do a good job of research without teaching.
And if you look at laboratories that are divorced from universities, they never last for more than, they're never very good for more than a generation.
They don't reproduce themselves.
You need to have young people, and you need to have the
the enthusiasm, the energy, the iconoclasm, and the confidence that young people, young scientists have.
And so it was quite essential from my point of view that we should have good graduate students here at Scripps.
But guys like Art Maxwell and Johnny Knauss and some of the others,
had a hard time with their doctoral exams.
And I thought the reason for it was a lot of them did.
Not just those two, but those were two outstanding people who had trouble with their doctoral exams.
I thought the reason for it was that they were divorced from the basic sciences.
We were 120 miles away from UCLA.
It was a killing trip to get up there.
The people who came down here
tended to stay here and not to take any more courses in physics or chemistry or biology or mathematics or engineering, which are basic to oceanographic research or oceanographic work.
Oceanography is not really a science.
Oceanography is the application of science to an object of study, namely the ocean, and what lives in the ocean, what's beneath the ocean, what's above the ocean.
whole range of phenomena of the watery part of our planet.
And therefore what you need is good physicists and good chemists and good biologists, who at the same time are fascinated by this complex set of phenomena that occur in the ocean.
And I think you need people who are, you need at least some of these people to be trained in oceanographic institutions.
as graduate students.
The reason I do is that going to sea is more than just an art.
Doing science at sea, there's an artistic component to it.
But it also takes a certain kind of scientific imagination and scientific planning.
And even more important,
Every part of the ocean is related to every other part of the ocean.
You can't do marine physics very well without also knowing something about marine chemistry and marine biology.
The story I told you about the snapping shrimp and the deep scattering layer illustrates that very well indeed.
You need to have respect for and understanding of, if you're a physical oceanographer, what the biologists know and what they're interested in, and vice versa.
So that means that you really need
Some people to be trained in an oceanographic institution will have this breadth of view and special kind of experience.
On the other hand, they also need to know as much basic science as possible.
It's a tough business to do both those things.
And it's essentially impossible if the nearest university, basic university, is 120 miles away.
Woods Hole has discovered the same thing.
I thought of a way to solve this problem, which was to establish down here a graduate school of science and engineering, which I thought of as like Caltech.
If you look at Caltech, it's got mostly graduate students.
It's only got 500 undergraduates and about 1,500 graduate students.
The only difference would be that this would be a state-supported institution rather than a privately-supported institution.
But in those days, that difference didn't look like it was very much of a difference, because everybody was riding high.
Prosperity was not only around the corner, it was here with a bang for the bang.
And the taxes income of the University of California was increasing by leaps and bounds, even though everybody always poor-mouthed it.
I got a good deal of support from the Chamber of Commerce and the industrial, the conveyor and the other industrial people in San Diego.
And I brought Rosson Bennett out here, the man I told you about before.
By this time he was chief of Naval Research, head of the Office of Naval Research.
And he made a speech.
He had been here before.
He was well known in San Diego because he'd been

His last job before becoming chief of the Bureau of Naval Research was he was commander of the Naval Electronics Laboratory, director of the Naval Electronics Laboratory, which was the old Navy radio and sound laboratory.
That's a big job.
He was well known.
He came out and gave a speech to local citizens, including the city manager and the mayor and the bigwigs of San Diego.
and said that the Navy was all for this, and would support it vigorously, and would support research there, and also said it was a damn good thing for San Diego, which he knew well.
And it was a very powerful and very effective speech.
And the people of San Diego wanted this anyhow, so this was just an added bonus.
But the main thing that Rawson did was to
overcome the opposition of other campuses of the university, particularly UCLA.
It was always very jealous of us because we never did much teaching and we got lots of money from the government and lots of members of the National Academy and things like that.
Not many by that time, but still several at that time.
Several.
More than they had at UCLA.
And the worst blow of all to the UCLA people was when we persuaded Harold Urey to come out here.
I'd gotten to know Harold pretty well in Washington in connection with my interest in geochemistry.

I went to see him and persuaded him to come, to get to the Scripps Institution, having in mind, however, that we would have this School of Science and Engineering about the same time Jim Arnold came here, and him, Craig, and Hans Seuss, who were very, particularly Hans Seuss was a great scientist, recognized as one.
I guess they came first, and then Harold.
Anyhow, you guys at UCLA took a very dim view of our getting Urey.
And they insisted to Sproul that he not be a professor at Scripps, but a professor at large in the university.
So if they could claim two, particularly a man named Louis Slichter, who was director of the Institute of Geophysics, felt this way.
Because he said, if I hadn't talked Harold into coming here, he would have come to UCLA.
He might or might not.
Anyhow, there were a series of committees from the other campuses that took a very dim view of this school of science and engineering.
The engineers said that we can do the whole job for the university extension.
One of the reasons for having it was to upgrade the quality of the engineers and scientists that were working for Aurora and Solar and Convair and the other high technology industries here.
And they had, the School of Engineering at UCLA had a program down here which was designed to do this.
And they said, why can't we just expand that?
But Glenn Seaborg came down on one of these committees, and Ernest Lawrence was on that committee, too.
And they were from Berkeley, which is far enough away so we weren't a threat.
And they always liked big ideas.
So they enthusiastically backed it.
And the result was that the regents voted to establish it.
This was about 1956 or 57.
And the city of San Diego voted to give the university high-speed art.
I'm a little bit confused about the actual detailed sequence of events.
The upshot or the fact was that the School of Science and Engineering never got off the ground, even though the city had voted this as 50 acres of land.
And the reason was that the regents got a bigger idea.
There was a state office of education report
based upon demographic projections of the future of California.
They said we were going to have 50 million people here by the year 2000.
Those were the days when the birth rate was right in the middle of the baby boom.
Birth rate was still going up.
And people were flocking into California because of the rise of high technology industry here.
And all the projections showed the population of California just going up and up to 50 million people by the end of the century.
So they decided, and it was recommended,
All three segments of public higher education in California should be expanded.
Those were the junior colleges, which were locally paid for and locally managed by cities out of the city taxes, like public schools, but with a contribution from the state colleges, which
offered a full four-year college education to a rather large percentage of high school graduates.
And the university, which offered not only undergraduate but also graduate education and research, and had a very restrictive admissions policy, only the top one-eighth of the high school graduates.
And this admissions policy was

formalized by the Coordinating Board of Higher Education of California, composed of four segments, three public segments plus a private college, that the uni colleges would admit every high school graduate, state colleges would admit the top 35%, and the University of California the top 12.5% as freshmen, and that they would also
The university would also have met graduates of the junior colleges who were qualified.
And they decided on that basis that they needed three new campuses of 27,500 students each.
And they would also expand Santa Barbara and Riverside and Davis.
that they would have these three big new campuses.
And one of these was going to be in Northern California and two in Southern California.
And it seemed logical that one of them would be in San Diego County.
Two in the Los Angeles area.
I mean, one in the Los Angeles area, one new one in the Los Angeles area, plus UCLA.
One new one in Northern California.
And so they sort of put the School of Science and Engineering on the back burner and decided to go ahead with a search for sites for these three new campuses.
And the firm of Pereira and Luckman, the architectural firm of Pereira and Luckman, got the job of making a survey of where the new campus in San Diego County should be.
I thought right from the very beginning it should be right as close as possible to the Scripps Institution of Oceanography.
The alternative would have been to build up the School of Science and Engineering, which they agreed to, and which they got the land for.
